In short, I finished Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus and finally realized it's the best game in the series.

The first games were a bit of a trial run, but here the guys have really done a great job. The graphics have been improved, and while there are games with better graphics now, the graphics in this game are excellent. The physics and animations have been pumped up when enemies fly apart, it looks incredibly cool.

The story in Wolfenstein was never a strong point, but here it's interesting. The most memorable mission is the one where you're in a wheelchair... and taking down Nazis. It's simply brilliant.

The developers have really worked on the gunplay. The weapons feel real, and each gun has its own weight. The enemies aren't just dumb bots; they actually coordinate their actions, shouting at each other, trying to outflank them. They all look different, so you can immediately tell who you're dealing with.

Difficulty wise... Especially on Mein Leben... It's excruciatingly difficult, but doable. By the end, the Destroyer kept killing me, even though I knew how to defeat it. I was just rushing and doing stupid things. On this difficulty level, you have to constantly stealth, which can be tiring at times, but it's so satisfying when you get through the entire location without a hitch.

BJ weapon upgrades and enhancements are thoughtfully crafted. These aren't just stats, they're truly gameplay-changing. Stilts or the squeezing device aren't just new abilities, they're full-fledged mechanics that add incredible variety.

The most amazing thing is that in 10 hours of play, I experienced more emotions and more memorable moments than in hundreds of hours in some open-world game where all you do is run from marker to marker.

After projects like these, you realize that creating games isn't just a business. It's a responsibility. Responsibility for the story, for the atmosphere, for every element of gameplay. And most importantly, there are no cases, donation currency, or mandatory online play. It's a pure gaming experience. Special respect to the developers for this

Played the 2009 episode, The New Order and The Old Blood (and I still remember how very different the latter two were from the former, after all the franchise had been handed to MachineGames) in the mid 2010s but took all these years to get here because of a long hiatus in "active" gaming. After hearing disparate things about this game, I think some criticism is fair, other unwarranted.

So better start from the bottom.
TNO was good at mixing over the top elements with drama, especially when showing a world mostly fallen under Nazi rule; here, the balance too often tips on the former side, resulting in moments that are too silly and overacted, some truly insufferable characters (who thought Spesh was good to have such a large role in the middle part of the game?), and at least a couple times where I wondered if the story hadn't jumped the shark. Given the theme of the game, expecting for it to not be political is silly and TNO was not subtle but this is far too unsubtle. And the less is said about that infamous scene with Anya near the end, the better.
On the gameplay side, damage feedback is really bad and, even with the maps, navigating a level can be quite difficult at times, like correctly identifying crawlspaces. The New York maps are among the most impressive and detailed, even just for the shock and awe of seeing the city reduced to a nuclear wasteland, but turn into the biggest pain after a while. Also for a game where you can also play stealthy, I'm suprised that some traversal abilities are inferior to a not-stealthy game like Doom.
I don't get why some people said this game was short, it's far from it, but the disappointment likely stems from how anticlimatic the ending feels, even more as the content you can tackle after it (but even before that) is just Ubercommander missions that consist in replaying maps - padding. The sensation may have been further soured by how the following episode turned out, but that's a story for another day.
I also felt that beside the Venus sections and the always etremely cool tech, the game had nothing to really impress me style-wise but that's a likely consequence of playing the predecessor when it was still new, compared to this one. At least the pop-in issues I saw plenty of times in TNO back then, were rare and small occurrences here.

However, excluding the padded content, the experience has been extremely satisfying in the end, to the point of becoming the only game I'd play during its second half, maybe not coincidentally a point where the story, after getting extremely bleak, starts becoming more optimistic and hopeful. 
What I recalled most fondly about TNO was that, even if the enemy AI can get quite dumb (something MachineGames seems unable or unwilling to fix, given what I've heard about their recent Indiana Jones game), for most of the time going guns blazing, or stealthy, or a mix of the two was always valid, something that has stayed here. I love going silently, popping heads with the silenced pistol from a distance, to eliminate commanders only to then find a lasergewehr and mow down any remaining resistance in the area. I also like that, at first, you may go without even looking at the perks, and only after a while realize that you're effectively getting the ones that fit your playstyle.
There's an impressive number of collectibles, including the return of the records from these alternate early Sixties. So many that, in fact, I could have lived without those Star Cards. Lore items are plenty and I love how they make this world feel more lived-in, like letters and other texts that humanize some Nazi officers and soldiers while not making them necessarily sympathetic, going with the theme that it's an error to think only monsters could do atrocities, it's "merely" human beings.
The story has embarassing lows but when it reaches highs, it really does. The character of Sigrun Engel and her arc, the unflattering portrayal of an aged Hitler, or the whole part in the town of Roswell - it's in fact one of those games that, in light of the social and political situations ongoing in the mid 2020s, can even leave feeling chills down your spine. Frau Engel has not even that much screen time but also thanks to that, she steals the scene in every apperance.
Also ignoring once again the padded content, it's quite replayable not just for the mixing of gameplay styles it allows for the most part, but to experience the differences in the Wyatt and Fergus timelines.

There are also no hit markers for enemies which can be kind of annoying, especially because many maps have environmental effects that reduce visibility. The cover system is also kind of janky. I don't know if it works better on keyboard and mouse). Luckily(?) cover is of limited use, because like in other Wolfenstein games many enemies will simply run up to you and start firing point-blank. 

There is also an "issue" with graphics/performance...kind of. I have an NVIDIA geforce GTX 1080--not exactly a powerhouse, so I did some provisional downgrading of a few video/graphics settings before beginning to play and the game consistently ran at 60fps while still looking good. After a couple hours of playing though the game I got a notification that my memory had been maxed out (I have 32gb RAM) and that I should further reduce my settings or potentially suffer performance issues. So I did this. Still wound up getting the same message, still saw no drop in performance. Once it became apparent I wasn't simply getting lucky avoiding crashes/freezes and was actually running the game fine, I turned settings back up to what they were previously and continued playing without issue despite this notification continuing to come up at the start of each play session. Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour – 500 g
Water – 200 ml
Egg – 1
Salt – 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes – 1 kg
Onions – 2
Lard or butter – 50 g
Salt – to taste
Ground black pepper – to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Sauté the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the sautéed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or sautéed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

The "kill the commander first" mechanic is a good idea on paper, but in practice it actually ruins the game for me. Which sucks because *every single encounter* works like this. I do not enjoy stealth in any form, so I don't have fun sneaking through levels. So I run and gun in. But all this does is floods the level with endlessly respawning enemies, whether the plot justifies it or not (how are infinite enemies fitting inside the limited space of a sealed-off submarine section, exactly?). In order to make the infinite respawning stop, you have to make a mad dash through the level and follow your compass reading that directly points to the commanders you need to kill in order for the infinite enemies to become finite. So...basically....you can either play stealth, or make a mad dash through EVERY SINGLE LEVEL before you even can get a chance to explore it to track down the f***ing commanders so you can walk around without enemies shooting at you. 

Like I said, this idea is great on paper. Players can pick their style of play: stealth, or a mad fire fight. But that fire fight is not a fun alternative to the stealth, because the only way to make the fight not a waste of ammo and health is to madly dash through the level not paying attention to anything but the compass that's tracking the commanders. THEN you get to backtrack through the level you just ran through because the enemies are all scattered behind you...it just feels like a mess and a waste of my time? I hated this feature in New Blood and I am disappointed it is still in this game. New Order was so much fun, I am bummed they didn't just continue with what worked with that. Oh well, I guess.
